title: ECZ G7 Eng Model Paper 1
subject: English
description: A comprehensive Grade 7 English examination following the ECZ Zambian curriculum format. This exam covers grammar, vocabulary, spelling, punctuation, comprehension, and paragraph organization skills essential for Grade 7 students.

questions.question:
**GRADE 7 ENGLISH MODEL EXAMINATION**

This examination consists of **60 questions** divided into **Section A** (Questions 1-38) and **Section B** (Questions 39-60). You have **90 minutes** to complete this exam.

**Section A** tests your knowledge of grammar, vocabulary, spelling, punctuation, and word meanings.
**Section B** focuses on paragraph organization and reading comprehension.

Read each question carefully and choose the best answer from the four options provided. Good luck!
questions.explanation: Introduction to the examination format and structure.

questions.question:
**SECTION A: GRAMMAR AND VOCABULARY**

**Part 1: Questions 2-21**
Each question contains a sentence with a word or group of words missing. Choose the word or group of words that makes the sentence correct.
questions.explanation: Instructions for Section A, Part 1

questions.question: The children ... playing in the garden when it started to rain.
questions.explanation: The subject 'children' is plural, so the past continuous tense requires 'were' as the auxiliary verb.

questions.question: My mother asked me to ... the dishes after dinner.
questions.explanation: After 'to' we use the base form of the verb (infinitive without 'to').

questions.question: The book ... on the table belongs to my sister.
questions.explanation: 'Lying' is the present participle of 'lie' (to be in a horizontal position), which is correct here.

questions.question: Neither John ... Mary came to the party yesterday.
questions.explanation: 'Neither' is always followed by 'nor' in correlative conjunctions.

questions.question: The teacher explained the lesson ... clearly that everyone understood.
questions.explanation: 'So' is used before adverbs (clearly) in the structure 'so + adverb + that'.

questions.question: By the time we arrived, the movie ... already started.
questions.explanation: Past perfect tense uses 'had' + past participle to show an action completed before another past action.

questions.question: She is ... intelligent student in our class.
questions.explanation: Superlative form requires 'the most' when comparing more than two people or things.

questions.question: I would like ... information about the school trip.
questions.explanation: 'Some' is used in positive statements and requests, especially with uncountable nouns like 'information'.

questions.question: The students ... their homework before the teacher arrived.
questions.explanation: Past perfect tense 'had finished' shows the homework was completed before the teacher's arrival (both past events).

questions.question: My father works ... a bank in the city center.
questions.explanation: 'At' is used with specific locations like banks, schools, and offices.

questions.question: If it ... tomorrow, we will stay at home.
questions.explanation: In first conditional sentences, we use simple present tense after 'if' and future tense in the main clause.

questions.question: The cat ... under the bed when the dog barked.
questions.explanation: Simple past tense 'hid' is correct for a completed action in the past.

questions.question: She speaks English ... than her brother.
questions.explanation: Comparative form 'better' is used when comparing two people's abilities.

questions.question: The children are excited ... their school trip next week.
questions.explanation: The adjective 'excited' is followed by the preposition 'about'.

questions.question: My grandmother ... me interesting stories when I was young.
questions.explanation: Simple past tense 'told' is correct for actions that happened regularly in the past.

questions.question: There ... many people at the market yesterday.
questions.explanation: 'Were' is the correct past tense form for plural subjects like 'people'.

questions.question: The boy ... his bicycle to school every day.
questions.explanation: Simple present tense with third person singular requires 's' ending: 'rides'.

questions.question: We have been waiting ... the bus for thirty minutes.
questions.explanation: The verb 'wait' is followed by the preposition 'for' when indicating what we're waiting for.

questions.question: Could you please ... me with my homework tonight?
questions.explanation: After modal verbs like 'could', we use the base form of the verb.

questions.question:
**Part 2: Questions 22-26**
Each question has a sentence with one word missing. Choose the word that is correctly spelt.
questions.explanation: Instructions for Part 2 - Spelling

questions.question: The ... of the story was very interesting.
questions.explanation: 'Beginning' is spelled with double 'n' in the middle and single 'n' at the end.

questions.question: She made a ... mistake in her mathematics test.
questions.explanation: 'Serious' is spelled with 'i' before 'o' and ends with single 's'.

questions.question: The students were ... to submit their assignments on time.
questions.explanation: 'Necessary' has one 'c' and double 's' in the middle.

questions.question: My ... subject at school is science.
questions.explanation: 'Favourite' (British spelling) includes 'ou' in the middle and ends with 'ite'.

questions.question: The weather was ... for our picnic yesterday.
questions.explanation: 'Beautiful' has 'eau' at the beginning and ends with single 'l'.

questions.question:
**Part 3: Questions 28-32**
Each question has four sentences that are almost the same, but only one has correct punctuation. Choose the correctly punctuated sentence.
questions.explanation: Instructions for Part 3 - Punctuation

questions.question: Choose the correctly punctuated sentence:
options: My teacher said 'Please complete your homework tonight.'
My teacher said, 'Please complete your homework tonight.'
My teacher said: 'Please complete your homework tonight'.
My teacher said; 'Please complete your homework tonight.'
questions.explanation: A comma should separate the reporting verb from direct speech, and the period goes inside the quotation marks.

questions.question: Choose the correctly punctuated sentence:
options: The fruits in the basket are: apples oranges and bananas.
The fruits in the basket are; apples, oranges, and bananas.
The fruits in the basket are apples, oranges, and bananas.
The fruits in the basket are: apples, oranges and, bananas.
questions.explanation: Items in a series are separated by commas, and no colon is needed after 'are'.

questions.question: Choose the correctly punctuated sentence:
options: Dear Sir I am writing to complain about the service.
Dear Sir, I am writing to complain about the service.
Dear Sir: I am writing to complain about the service.
Dear, Sir I am writing to complain about the service.
questions.explanation: In letter greetings, a comma follows the salutation in informal letters.

questions.question: Choose the correctly punctuated sentence:
options: The students book was left on the desk.
The student's book was left on the desk.
The students' book was left on the desk.
The students book's was left on the desk.
questions.explanation: An apostrophe and 's' show possession for a single student.

questions.question: Choose the correctly punctuated sentence:
options: After eating dinner we watched television.
After eating, dinner we watched television.
After eating dinner, we watched television.
After eating dinner we, watched television.
questions.explanation: A comma separates an introductory phrase from the main clause.

questions.question:
**Part 4: Questions 34-39**
Each question has a word, group of words, or sentence underlined. Choose the option that gives the correct meaning of the underlined part.
questions.explanation: Instructions for Part 4 - Word meanings

questions.question: The old man walked **slowly** down the street.
questions.explanation: 'Slowly' means at a slow pace or not quickly.

questions.question: She felt **exhausted** after the long journey.
questions.explanation: 'Exhausted' means extremely tired or worn out.

questions.question: The **ancient** building was built many years ago.
questions.explanation: 'Ancient' means very old or from a long time ago.

questions.question: He **whispered** the secret to his friend.
questions.explanation: 'Whispered' means spoke in a very quiet voice.

questions.question: The teacher **praised** the student for good work.
questions.explanation: 'Praised' means complimented or expressed approval.

questions.question:
**SECTION B: PARAGRAPH ORGANIZATION AND COMPREHENSION**

**Part 1: Questions 40-46**
Each question has four paragraphs. Choose the paragraph which has sentences in the best order.
questions.explanation: Instructions for Section B, Part 1

questions.question: Choose the paragraph with sentences in the best order:
options: First, we gathered all the ingredients. Then, we mixed them together carefully. After that, we baked the cake for thirty minutes. Finally, we decorated it with frosting.
Finally, we decorated it with frosting. First, we gathered all the ingredients. After that, we baked the cake for thirty minutes. Then, we mixed them together carefully.
Then, we mixed them together carefully. Finally, we decorated it with frosting. First, we gathered all the ingredients. After that, we baked the cake for thirty minutes.
After that, we baked the cake for thirty minutes. Then, we mixed them together carefully. Finally, we decorated it with frosting. First, we gathered all the ingredients.
questions.explanation: The logical sequence follows the actual order of baking: gathering ingredients, mixing, baking, then decorating.

questions.question: Choose the paragraph with sentences in the best order:
options: She opened the door and found a package. She was expecting visitors that day. She heard a knock at the door. She was surprised to see it was from her aunt.
She heard a knock at the door. She opened the door and found a package. She was surprised to see it was from her aunt. She was expecting visitors that day.
She was expecting visitors that day. She heard a knock at the door. She opened the door and found a package. She was surprised to see it was from her aunt.
She was surprised to see it was from her aunt. She was expecting visitors that day. She heard a knock at the door. She opened the door and found a package.
questions.explanation: The logical sequence: expecting visitors (context), hearing knock, opening door, being surprised by the package.

questions.question: Choose the paragraph with sentences in the best order:
options: The lion roared loudly to warn other animals. Other animals ran away quickly. A lion appeared from behind the trees. The forest became quiet again.
A lion appeared from behind the trees. The lion roared loudly to warn other animals. Other animals ran away quickly. The forest became quiet again.
Other animals ran away quickly. A lion appeared from behind the trees. The lion roared loudly to warn other animals. The forest became quiet again.
The forest became quiet again. Other animals ran away quickly. The lion roared loudly to warn other animals. A lion appeared from behind the trees.
questions.explanation: Logical sequence: lion appears, roars, animals run, forest becomes quiet.

questions.question: Choose the paragraph with sentences in the best order:
options: The match ended with our team winning 2-1. The players practiced hard for weeks. Yesterday was the final football match. Both teams played very well during the game.
Yesterday was the final football match. The players practiced hard for weeks. Both teams played very well during the game. The match ended with our team winning 2-1.
The players practiced hard for weeks. Yesterday was the final football match. Both teams played very well during the game. The match ended with our team winning 2-1.
Both teams played very well during the game. The players practiced hard for weeks. Yesterday was the final football match. The match ended with our team winning 2-1.
questions.explanation: Chronological order: practice (preparation), match day, game performance, result.

questions.question: Choose the paragraph with sentences in the best order:
options: She felt very proud of her achievement. She studied every day for the examination. The results were announced last week. She passed with excellent marks.
She studied every day for the examination. The results were announced last week. She passed with excellent marks. She felt very proud of her achievement.
The results were announced last week. She studied every day for the examination. She passed with excellent marks. She felt very proud of her achievement.
She passed with excellent marks. She felt very proud of her achievement. She studied every day for the examination. The results were announced last week.
questions.explanation: Chronological sequence: studying, results announcement, passing, feeling proud.

questions.question: Choose the paragraph with sentences in the best order:
options: The fire was put out after two hours. The fire brigade arrived quickly. Someone called the fire brigade immediately. A fire started in the old building.
A fire started in the old building. Someone called the fire brigade immediately. The fire brigade arrived quickly. The fire was put out after two hours.
The fire brigade arrived quickly. A fire started in the old building. Someone called the fire brigade immediately. The fire was put out after two hours.
Someone called the fire brigade immediately. The fire was put out after two hours. A fire started in the old building. The fire brigade arrived quickly.
questions.explanation: Logical sequence: fire starts, someone calls brigade, brigade arrives, fire extinguished.

questions.question: Choose the paragraph with sentences in the best order:
options: The children played happily in the new playground. The school decided to build a playground. Many parents donated money for the project. The playground was completed last month.
The school decided to build a playground. Many parents donated money for the project. The playground was completed last month. The children played happily in the new playground.
Many parents donated money for the project. The children played happily in the new playground. The school decided to build a playground. The playground was completed last month.
The playground was completed last month. The school decided to build a playground. Many parents donated money for the project. The children played happily in the new playground.
questions.explanation: Logical progression: decision made, funding obtained, project completed, children using playground.

questions.question:
**Part 2: Questions 48-61 - Reading Comprehension**

This part contains **three texts** with questions following each. Read each text carefully before answering the questions.

**TEXT 1: The School Garden**

Read the passage below and answer questions 49-52.
questions.explanation: Introduction to Reading Comprehension section

questions.question:
**TEXT 1** 

 Greenwood Primary School has a beautiful garden behind the main building. The garden was started five years ago by Mrs. Banda, the science teacher, with help from Grade 7 students. Today, the garden has many different vegetables including tomatoes, onions, cabbage, and carrots. There are also fruit trees like mangoes and oranges.

Every morning before classes begin, students take turns watering the plants. They also help with weeding and harvesting the vegetables. The school uses the vegetables in the feeding program, which provides lunch for all students. Any extra vegetables are sold to parents and the money is used to buy seeds and garden tools.

The garden has taught students many important lessons. They have learned about different types of plants, how plants grow, and the importance of taking care of the environment. Students also learn to work together as a team. Mrs. Banda says the garden project has been very successful and plans to expand it next year.
Who started the school garden?
questions.explanation: The text clearly states that 'The garden was started five years ago by Mrs. Banda, the science teacher, with help from Grade 7 students.'

questions.question: What vegetables are grown in the garden?
questions.explanation: The passage specifically mentions 'tomatoes, onions, cabbage, and carrots' as the vegetables grown.

questions.question: How is the money from selling extra vegetables used?
options: To buy seeds and garden tools
questions.explanation: The text states 'Any extra vegetables are sold to parents and the money is used to buy seeds and garden tools.'

questions.question: What is one important lesson students learn from the garden?
options: The importance of taking care of the environment
questions.explanation: The passage mentions students learn 'the importance of taking care of the environment' among other lessons.

questions.question:
**TEXT 2: The Lost Puppy**

Read the passage below and answer questions 53-57. 

Last Saturday morning, eight-year-old Chanda was playing in her yard when she heard a soft whimpering sound coming from behind the house. She followed the sound and found a small, brown puppy hiding under a bush. The puppy looked scared and hungry.

Chanda carefully picked up the puppy and took it inside to show her mother. 'Mum, can we keep it?' she asked hopefully. Her mother examined the puppy and noticed it was wearing a collar with a name tag that read 'Simba.' She explained to Chanda that the puppy belonged to someone else and they needed to find its owner.

They decided to walk around the neighbourhood asking people if they had lost a puppy. After visiting several houses, they met Mr. Mwanza, who lived three streets away. When he saw Simba, his face lit up with joy. 'Thank you so much!' he said. 'Simba has been missing since yesterday. My children have been crying all night.'

Chanda felt happy that she had helped reunite Simba with his family, even though she was a little sad to say goodbye. Mr. Mwanza thanked Chanda by giving her a box of chocolates and promising to visit with Simba soon.
questions.explanation: Introduction to Text 2

questions.question: Where did Chanda find the puppy?
options: Under a bush behind the house
questions.explanation: The text states 'She followed the sound and found a small, brown puppy hiding under a bush.'

questions.question: How did they know the puppy belonged to someone?
options: It was wearing a collar with a name tag
questions.explanation: The passage mentions 'it was wearing a collar with a name tag that read Simba.'

questions.question: What was the puppy's name?
questions.explanation: The name tag on the collar read 'Simba.'

questions.question: How did Mr. Mwanza thank Chanda?
options: He gave her a box of chocolates
questions.explanation: The text states 'Mr. Mwanza thanked Chanda by giving her a box of chocolates.'

questions.question: How long had Simba been missing?
questions.explanation: Mr. Mwanza said 'Simba has been missing since yesterday.'

questions.question:
**TEXT 3: Traditional Zambian Games**

Read the passage below and answer questions 59-61.

Zambia has many traditional games that children have enjoyed for hundreds of years. One popular game is called 'Nsolo,' which is played with small stones or seeds on a wooden board with holes. Players take turns moving the stones around the board following special rules. The player who captures the most stones wins the game.

Another favorite game is 'Hide and Seek,' known locally as 'Chiselu.' Children take turns hiding while one person counts and then tries to find all the hidden players. This game helps children develop their problem-solving skills and learn to work as a team.

'Rope skipping' or 'Ukujumpa' is especially popular among girls. They use ropes made from plant fibers or rubber and create songs to sing while jumping. Some girls can jump for many minutes without stopping, showing great skill and coordination.

These traditional games are important because they bring children together, teach them valuable life skills, and help preserve Zambian culture. Unfortunately, many children today prefer modern games and computers, so some traditional games are being forgotten. Parents and teachers are working hard to make sure these games continue to be played by future generations.
questions.explanation: Introduction to Text 3

questions.question: What is 'Nsolo' played with?
questions.explanation: The text states that Nsolo 'is played with small stones or seeds on a wooden board with holes.'

questions.question: What do girls use to make ropes for skipping?
questions.explanation: The passage mentions 'They use ropes made from plant fibers or rubber.'

questions.question: According to the passage, why are traditional games important?
options: They bring children together and teach life skills
They are better than modern games
questions.explanation: The text states traditional games 'bring children together, teach them valuable life skills, and help preserve Zambian culture.'
